The biggest turning point in American history is arguably the mid-term elections of 1892, because that is when the real distinctions between the political parties began to disappear. The support of Democrats for individual liberty and free markets began to disappear. By the elections of 1896, the major parties had become indistinguishable in their ideologies: They favored large, intrusive, centralized government, and, especially, the use of government promote and benefit larges businesses and industry. From 1896 on, the parties struggled to distinguish themselves from one another, and grew increasingly to favor govern-ment as the leading social force. Today— and for some time— the major political parties are but one political class, with rival factions, both advocating and benefiting from the Leviathan federal government that holds sway today.
